title: After jettisoning warmonger Bolton, Trump emerges as a left winger on foreign policy
text:
Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images) John Bolton never quite saw eye-to-eye with Donald Trump.

How unstable is President Donald Trump’s White House? A look at just one vitally important post — national-security adviser — tells the story.

With the ouster on Tuesday of John Bolton (next stop: “Dancing With the Stars”?) and the appointment of Charlie Kupperman as acting national-security adviser, Trump is now on his fifth guy. This includes convicted felon Mike Flynn, who’s scheduled to be sentenced in December for lying to the FBI about his dealings with Russia.

Five security advisers in 32 months — months. Barack Obama, George W. Bush and Bill Clinton had seven in 24 years. Combined. Richard Nixon Gerald Ford, Jimmy Carter and George H.W. Bush combined had four in 16 years. And, again, that’s one key job.

Instability, uncertainty, lack of coherence and lack of clarity are not conducive to keeping the nation safe.

Where we stand

Trump has lurched from one adviser to the next, talking loudly about everything he would do, and yet here we are nearly three years in and here’s where we stand:

• North Korea has built more nuclear weapons.

• Iran has taken advantage of Trump’s pullout from the P5+1 agreement to move closer to having a weapon of its own.

• A growing trans-Atlantic rift is Vladimir Putin’s wildest fantasy come true.

• And rather than kowtowing to Trump like Trump said it would (“Trade wars are easy to win,” he foolishly bragged), China has instead accelerated its “China 2025” program, designed to gain dominance over America in artificial intelligence, 5G, robotics, aerospace, pharmaceuticals and all the rest.

Trump has had some successes, but they are few and of the lower-level variety.

Meantime, does anyone remember Franklin D. Roosevelt inviting Tojo over after Pearl Harbor to talk things over? How about the time when George W. Bush and then Barack Obama extended an olive branch to Osama bin Laden and invited him to Camp David? Such a hoot.

Wait — none of that happened.

Yet Trump thinks it’s a swell idea to invite the Taliban — the same terrorists who have been harboring al Qaeda and murdering Americans for years — to Camp David. Why not treat them to a ride on Air Force One and throw them a state dinner while he’s at it?

Surprising twist

Which brings us to this observation: Trump has been called many things, but here’s something you may find new: When it comes to foreign policy, he’s a left-wing radical. You heard me: Trump’s a major-league leftie.

After all, Trump, as president:

• Has questioned the role of NATO, and even suggested that America could get out of the 70-year-old military alliance.

• Eagerly set foot in North Korea, and praised its murderous leader — and killer of Americans — Kim Jong Un. Trump has said he respects him, and, what’s more: “We fell in love.”

• Has tried to curry favor with Kim by criticizing U.S.–South Korean military exercises as financially wasteful.

• Said he’d talk with the leaders of Iran without preconditions.

• And, of course, praises dictators galore: Russia’s Putin, China’s Xi Jinping and every other global rogue he can find, at every opportunity.

Of course, the Obama administration, too, was willing to talk with Iran without preconditions, but can you recall Obama saying he fell in love with Hassan Rouhani, let alone Kim, or that we should get out of NATO? He didn’t.

Trump is also much further to the left on foreign policy than another president he likes to malign: Jimmy Carter. Carter personally forged a peace deal between Israel and Egypt — doing more to secure Israel’s security than Trump has ever done. (What has he done, exactly, anyway?)

Tough on Russians

Carter was also tough on the Russians. After Moscow invaded Afghanistan in 1979, Carter cut off shipments of food, killed an arms-control deal, boycotted the Moscow Olympics, and began arming the mujahadeen. Reagan supporters take credit for the latter, but, in his memoir “From the Shadows,” Robert Gates, the former defense secretary and CIA director, points out that it actually began on Carter’s watch.

Like I said: On foreign policy, Trump is far-left guy. Barack Obama, Jimmy Carter — all the guys Trump sneers at — were actually to the right of him, and got more done.

The ouster of Bolton is a good thing. He is a lifelong warmonger who never saw an armed conflict he didn’t like. The fear that he would drag Trump into a new war — Iran has always been Public Enemy No. 1 in Bolton’s eyes — has gone.

The questions now: Who will be the new Trump whisperer, and how long will he or she last?
description: When it comes to foreign policy Donald Trump is a left-wing radical, writes Paul Brandus.
